nodes.text: The guard shack vestibule smells like dust and toner. (pause) A desk sits under a dead intercom speaker, waiting to be blamed. (pause) The drawer is labeled in block letters: RETIRED ACCESS MEDIA—DO NOT RE-ISSUE.

You pull the drawer open. (pause) Old contractor badges lie in a shallow tray. (pause) Most are clipped to yellowing index cards. (pause) One badge: magnetic stripe scored through, taped over, scored again—like someone argued with it in stages.
A handwritten note on the tray: “These are not ‘active.’ Do not create new access events.” (pause) The quotation marks look defensive.
Beneath the badges is a thin sign-out sheet: CUSTODY (INFORMAL). (pause) Someone underlined “INFORMAL” so hard the paper nearly cut.
Entries are half names, full excuses: “TEMP—returning-after-calibration.” “Borrowed-for-audit-photos(not-use).” “Removed-from-circulation(pending-decision).”
Any of these still valid?
No one answers. (pause) Paper does not answer, because it only persists. (pause) The demagnetized badge has a sticker: DO NOT DISCARD. (pause) Someone wrote over it: DO NOT PROCESS.
The badge insert dispenser is an old slot. (pause) A faded placard reads: INSERT — WAIT FOR GREEN — REMOVE. (pause) “GREEN” is circled twice. (pause) Like reassurance didn’t take the first time.
Let’s see.
You feed the demagnetized badge into the slot. The machine pulls it in with polite certainty.
[SFX] A small motor whirs. A beep tries to happen and stops halfway.
The light stays stubbornly amber. The badge returns, slightly warmer, as if that helped.
Demag.
The dispenser prints a slip: UNREADABLE — REFER TO SECURITY. The end curls, ashamed to exist.

The speaker grille is painted over. (pause) Then it’s scraped clean in a rectangle, where a label used to be. (pause) The push-to-talk button is replaced with a toggle switch. (pause) It doesn’t commit to either position.
Security, this is OLEA field. Anyone on?
[INTERCOM VOICE] This line is monitored for safety and training. (pause) Not in real time. (pause) Not the same as “unmonitored”— just manage your expectations.
Found old contractor badges in the vestibule drawer. One’s demagnetized.

[INTERCOM VOICE] Okay. So. Don’t use it. (pause) Using it creates an access attempt. (pause) That creates a question. (pause) That creates a file. (pause) We are not funded for additional files this quarter.
I’m taking it.

[INTERCOM VOICE] I can’t authorize that. (pause) I also can’t stop you. (pause) Different form. (pause) Take it and it’s “in custody.” (pause) I have to ask whose custody. (pause) You’ll say your name. (pause) I’ll write it down, and then—

choices.text: Ask who’s responsible for these badges.
Persuade: [OLEA] Log it as salvage for closure.

nodes.text: [INTERCOM VOICE] Historically? Security. (pause) Practically? Nobody because “nobody” can’t be subpoenaed. (pause) Formally? Facilities—but only when the facility is active. (pause) And we are “mothballed”—a status with feelings.
So it’s orphaned.
[INTERCOM VOICE] It is “unassigned.” Orphaned implies duty.

[INTERCOM VOICE] You don’t. (pause) Request a replacement through Admin. (pause) Admin denies it because the site is in retirement posture. (pause) You cite operational necessity. (pause) Legal asks what operation. (pause) If you mean physically, there’s a mag encoder in the admin kiosk area. (pause) It may or may not be “forbidden.” (pause) The sticker fell off years ago.
Got it.
[INTERCOM VOICE] You did not “get it.” You acknowledged it. That’s safer for both of us.
Log it as salvage for closure. I’m maintaining chain-of-custody.

[INTERCOM VOICE] Chain-of-custody is a legal phrase. (pause) Please don’t say it like that. (pause) But— fine. (pause) If you insist on being correct: (pause) write your name on the informal sheet. (pause) Do not date it. (pause) Take a photo of the drawer label. (pause) It stays “context,” not an “event.”
That’s not how—
[INTERCOM VOICE] It is here. Please don’t make me be innovative about this.
[INTERCOM VOICE] Appreciated. For the record— there is no record of appreciation.
You take the demagnetized contractor badge. Tape on stripe catches your glove, reluctant to let go.
The drawer looks emptier than it should, like you’ve changed inventory by existing near it.
You push the drawer shut. (pause) It resists a second, then seats with a soft clack—like a stamp on the wrong form.
Nothing in the vestibule changes. Which is usually how the facility signals agreement.

choices.text: Leave down to Guard Shack Exterior.
Leave right to Admin Lobby and Kiosk.
